items.title: Unexpected whitespace inserted in Wakati mode
items.body:
I suspect that this bug is introduced in #111, sorry...

```python
import natto

print(natto.__version__)
nm = natto.MeCab('-Owakati')
print(nm.parse('この星の１等賞になりたいの、俺はっ！')[-1])
```

```
0.9.1
 # <- whitespace!!
```

items.title: Security vulnerability for Jinja (requirement for documentation generation)
items.body:
[CVE-2019-10906](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-462w-v97r-4m45)
high severity
Vulnerable versions: < 2.10.1
Patched version: 2.10.1
In Pallets Jinja before 2.10.1, str.format_map allows a sandbox escape.

[CVE-2016-10745](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-hj2j-77xm-mc5v)
high severity
Vulnerable versions: < 2.8.1
Patched version: 2.8.1
In Pallets Jinja before 2.8.1, str.format allows a sandbox escape.

items.title: Erroneous handling of whitespace trimming
items.body:
When stripping whitespace from input, we need to be sure to limit trimming only to half-width whitespace shars. Full-width whitespace is recognized and handled by MeCab, and so should be left intact.

Please see https://github.com/buruzaemon/natto-py/pull/111

items.title: requests security issue, CVE-2018-18074
items.body:
The Requests package before 2.20.0 for Python sends an HTTP Authorization header to an http URI upon receiving a same-hostname https-to-http redirect, which makes it easier for remote attackers to discover credentials by sniffing the network.

Upgrade requests to version 2.20.0 or later.

items.title: Add support for Python 3.7 for tests in Travis
items.body: Add support for Python 3.7 for tests run in Travis.

items.title: PyYAML security issue, CVE-2017-18342
items.body:
In PyYAML before 4.1, the yaml.load() API could execute arbitrary code. In other words, yaml.safe_load is not used.

Although this only involves the YAML-handling during testing, we should explicitly install a safe version of PyYAML during travis test runs.

Please see https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-18342

items.title: Make version string available in natto.MeCab
Enable -r/--rcfile MeCab option
items.body: The `-r/--rcfile` option is not available .

items.title: Node-formatting ignored when using Unidic unless -O is set to empty string
items.body:
As reported by @massongit in pull request #98 , node-formatting seems to be ignored by mecab when using Unidic. Please refer to [taku910/mecab#41](https://github.com/taku910/mecab/issues/41).

A workaround is to force natto-py to accept an empty string value for output `-O`.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Install Unidic 2.1.2
2. Execute code snippet A below to observe that natto-py will not be able to respect the node-formatting specified, but instead use the default `node-format` for Unidic
3. Contrast code snippet A (`natto-py`)with B and C (using `mecab` from command-line)

```
# Snippet A
# Note that node-formatting is ignored and defaults to node-format-unidic
>>> with MeCab(r'-d /opt/mecab/lib/mecab/dic/unidic -F%m\t%t,%f[12]\n') as nm:
...     for n in nm.parse('日本語だよ、これが。', as_nodes=True):
...         print(n.feature)
...
日本    ニッポン        ニッポン        日本    名詞-固有名詞-地名-国
語      ゴ      ゴ      語      名詞-普通名詞-一般
だ      ダ      ダ      だ      助動詞  助動詞-ダ       終止形-一般
よ      ヨ      ヨ      よ      助詞-終助詞
、                      、      補助記号-読点
これ    コレ    コレ    此れ    代名詞
が      ガ      ガ      が      助詞-格助詞
。                      。      補助記号-句点
EOS
```

```
# Snippet B
# Note that node-formatting is ignored and defaults to node-format-unidic
$ echo '日本語だよ、これが。' | mecab -d /opt/mecab/lib/mecab/dic/unidic/ -F%m\\t%t,%f[12]\\n
日本    ニッポン        ニッポン        日本    名詞-固有名詞-地名-国
語      ゴ      ゴ      語      名詞-普通名詞-一般
だ      ダ      ダ      だ      助動詞  助動詞-ダ       終止形-一般
よ      ヨ      ヨ      よ      助詞-終助詞
、                      、      補助記号-読点
これ    コレ    コレ    此れ    代名詞
が      ガ      ガ      が      助詞-格助詞
。                      。      補助記号-句点
EOS
```

```
# Snippet C
# node-formatting is honored when -O is passed an empty string!
$ echo '日本語だよ、これが。' | mecab -d /opt/mecab/lib/mecab/dic/unidic/ -F%m\\t%t,%f[12]\\n -O ""
日本    2,固
語      2,漢
だ      6,和
よ      6,和
、      3,記号
これ    6,和
が      6,和
。      3,記号
EOS
```

items.title: How to switch between two dictionaries?
items.body: I'm using Mecab to process both Japanese and Korean texts, I have two dictionary files. How do I specify a particular dictionary when instantiating Mecab in a function? Thank you!

items.title: Index out of range error message not being captured by natto-py
items.body:
When using output formatting in node parsing to capture the 8th token (pronunciation) for ipadic, the index out of range error message that is visible in `mecab` is not captured by natto-py.
   
To reproduce:

    from natto import MeCab

    nm = MeCab('-F%m,%f[0],%f[1],%f[8]')
    for n in nm.parse('私はアシャです', as_nodes=True):
        print(n.feature)
    ... 
    私,名詞,代名詞,ワタシ
    は,助詞,係助詞,ワ
    MECAB_NBEST request type is not set
    Traceback (most recent call last):
        File "/usr/home/buruzaemon/dev/github/natto-py/natto/mecab.py", line 400, in __parse_tonodes
        rawf = self.__ffi.string(sp)
        File "/usr/home/buruzaemon/dev/github/natto-py/.py35env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/cffi/api.py", line 288, in string
        return self._backend.string(cdata, maxlen)
    RuntimeError: cannot use string() on <cdata 'char *' NULL>

Compare with similar logic using `mecab`:

    $ mecab -F'%m,%f[0],%f[1],%f[8]\n'
    私はアシャです
    given index is out of range
    


Discovered indirectly in issue ["natto.api.MeCabError: MECAB_NBEST request type is not set" error under some circumstances](https://github.com/buruzaemon/natto-py/issues/95).

items.title: "natto.api.MeCabError: MECAB_NBEST request type is not set" error under some circumstances
items.body:
The following code will cause the "natto.api.MeCabError: MECAB_NBEST request type is not set" error


    # -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
    from natto import MeCab

    nm = MeCab('-F%m,%f[0],%f[1],%f[8]')
    for n in nm.parse('私はアシャです', as_nodes=True):
        print(n.feature)

items.body:

``` python
for n in nm.parse("おめぇ誰より卓球好きじゃんよ!", as_nodes=True):
    print(n.feature)
    break
```

I'm sorry but I don't have any clue about this error...

items.title: Need to deal with leading/trailing whitespace in tokens for boundary constraint parsing.

milestone.title: 0.4.0 Release
milestone.description:
boundary 指定の制約付き解析と lattice 上の API 関連のエンハンス。
Minor enhancements related to boundary constraint parsing and lattice API.

items.body:
Experimenting with the `-p` / `--partial` mode, it is clear that MeCab will silently eat any leading and trailing whitespace (ASCII `0x30`) characters in the tokens used in boundary constraint parsing.

Failure to do so will lead to errors with MeCab only spitting out `tokenizer.cpp(368) [new_node->feature]` before dumping core.

Add boundary constraint parsing to natto-py.

Please refer to:
https://mecab.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/mecab/doc/partial.html

http://qiita.com/yukinoi/items/4e7afb5e72b3a46da0f2

items.title: Debugging should use a kwarg
items.body: Make debugging optional via a keyword argument.

items.title: Node-parsing: return generator rather than array of nodes
items.body:
Initial implementation of node parsing in natto-py is naive in the sense that it materializes all the values of the node parsing, and then returns all of them in an list.

This is fine for parsing short strings, but this could become expensive in terms of space as the input text gets larger and larger.

Better to use a generator or some iterable instead of materializing all nodes and stuffing them into a list.

Originally opened 2014-12-02. 
This issue was ported from Bitbucket and is archived for historical reasons.

items.title: Python 3 input/output transformation as decorator
items.body:
The transformation of a Python 3 string (Unicode) to bytes (encoded in what mecab is expecting) for input, and vice versa for output, is sort of a hack.

How about using a decorator instead?

Originally opened 2014-11-05. 
This issue was ported from Bitbucket and is archived for historical reasons.

items.title: Reverse Issue 5: Python 2.7 input/output should really be strings and not Unicode
items.body:
Reverse the behavior change per Issue 5.

For Python 2.7, input/output should really be strings and not Unicode.
That should be the most expected behavior for most users.

But keep the behavior as it is for Python 3, as in Python 3 all strings are Unicode.

Originally opened 2014-11-21. 
This issue was ported from Bitbucket and is archived for historical reasons.

items.title: MeCabEnv: On Windows, use registry to guess at lib path
items.body:
On Windows platform, use winreg to obtain best-guess at path to libmecab.dll.

Originally opened 2014-11-19. 
This issue was ported from Bitbucket and is archived for historical reasons.

items.title: MeCab: destructor/clean-up for tagger reference
items.body:
Right now, clean-up is done via the [`with` context manager](http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343/).

Still, it would be nice to have some other way to ensure `mecab_destroy` is invoked to delete the tagger reference if `with` is not used.

Originally opened 2014-11-12. 
This issue was ported from Bitbucket and is archived for historical reasons.

items.title: All input / output should be in Unicode
items.body:
From [Porting your code to NLTK 3.0](https://github.com/nltk/nltk/wiki/Porting-your-code-to-NLTK-3.0): ...  

_NLTK3 requires all text input to be unicode and always return text as unicode_

Enhance the behavior of natto-py under Python 2.7 to make sure that this behavior is consistent. Python 3 behavior should be consistent with the above approach.

Originally opened 2014-11-12. 
This issue was ported from Bitbucket and is archived for historical reasons.

items.title: MeCab: add in path/name of mecab lib to string representation
items.body:
MIght be good to know what the natto.MeCab FFI-handle is actually pointed at.

Originally opened 2014-11-10.
This issue was ported from Bitbucket and is archived for historical reasons.

items.title: -u / --userdic / userdic option: Path including space char does not work on Windows
items.body:
## Problem Description

The [MeCab 0.996 option flags](http://mecab.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/mecab/doc/mecab.html) `-u` / `--userdic` / `user` for specifying a user-defined dictionary will not work via natto-py when its path is a Windows path including whitespace chars.
## Steps to reproduce the problem
1. Install MeCab 0.996.exe on Windows XP
2. Install Python 2.7.8
3. Install natto-py 0.0.2
4. Execute the following:

```
#!python
import natto
import os

os.environ['MECAB_PATH']='C:/Program Files/MeCab/bin/libmecab.dll'
os.environ['MECAB_CHARSET']='shift-jis'

nm = natto.MeCab('-u"C:\\Program Files\\MeCab\\dic\\mydictionary"')
```
- Observe that the above code results in the following exception being thrown:

```
#!python

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "natto\api.py", line 273, in __init__
    raise MeCabError(self._ERROR_INIT % str(verr))
natto.api.MeCabError: Could not initialize MeCab: unrecognized arguments: Files\MeCab\dic\mydictionary"
```
## Expected behavior

The reference to mecab via natto-py should be successfully instantiated.

Note that using `-u` / `--userdic` from the mecab command-line will work by simply surrounding the Windows path with double-quotes.

```
#!script

mecab -u"C:\Program Files\MeCab\dic\mydictionary"
```
## Version, platform, environment details
1. MeCab 0.996.exe
2. Windows XP Professional, Version 2002, Service Pack 3
3. Python 2.7.8
4. natto-py 0.0.2

Originally opened 2014-11-05. 
This issue was ported from Bitbucket and is archived for historical reasons.

items.title: -d / --dicdir / dicdir option: Path including space char does not work on Windows
items.body:
## Problem Description

The [MeCab 0.996 option flags](http://mecab.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/mecab/doc/mecab.html) `-d` / `--dicdir` / `dicdir` for specifying a system dictionary folder will not work via natto-py when its path is a Windows path including whitespace chars.
## Steps to reproduce the problem
1. Install MeCab 0.996.exe on Windows XP
2. Install Python 2.7.8
3. Install natto-py 0.0.2
4. Execute the following:

```
#!python
import natto
import os

os.environ['MECAB_PATH']='C:/Program Files/MeCab/bin/libmecab.dll'
os.environ['MECAB_CHARSET']='shift-jis'

nm = natto.MeCab('-d"C:\\Program Files\\MeCab\\dic\\ipadic"')
```
- Observe that the above code results in the following exception being thrown:

```
#!python

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "natto\api.py", line 273, in __init__
    raise MeCabError(self._ERROR_INIT % str(verr))
natto.api.MeCabError: Could not initialize MeCab: unrecognized arguments: Files\MeCab\dic\ipadic"
```
## Expected behavior

The reference to mecab via natto-py should be successfully instantiated, and the system dictionary folder path should be reflected in `nm.dicts[0].filename`.

Note that using `-d` / `--dicdir` from the mecab command-line will work by simply surrounding the Windows path with double-quotes.

```
#!script

mecab -d"C:\Program Files\MeCab\dic\ipadic"
```
## Version, platform, environment details
1. MeCab 0.996.exe
2. Windows XP Professional, Version 2002, Service Pack 3
3. Python 2.7.8
4. natto-py 0.0.2

Originally opened 2014-11-05.
Archiving for historical purposes.

items.title: -r / --rcfile / rcfile option: Path including space char does not work on Windows
items.body:
## Problem Description

The [MeCab 0.996 option flags](http://mecab.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/mecab/doc/mecab.html) `-r` / `--rcfile` / `rcfile` for specifying a resource file will not work via natto-py when the path is a Windows path including whitespace chars.
## Steps to reproduce the problem
1. Install MeCab 0.996.exe on Windows XP
2. Install Python 2.7.8
3. Install natto-py 0.0.2
4. Execute the following:

```
#!python
import natto
import os

os.environ['MECAB_PATH']='C:/Program Files/MeCab/bin/libmecab.dll'
os.environ['MECAB_CHARSET']='shift-jis'

nm = natto.MeCab("-rC:\Program Files\MeCab\etc\mymecabrc")
```
- Observe that the above code results in the following exception being thrown:

```
#!python

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "natto\api.py", line 273, in __init__
    raise MeCabError(self._ERROR_INIT % str(verr))
natto.api.MeCabError: Could not initialize MeCab: unrecognized arguments: -rC:\Program Files\MeCab\etc\mymecabrc
```
## Expected behavior

The reference to mecab via natto-py should be successfully instantiated.

Note that using `-r` / `--rcfile` from the mecab command-line will work by simply surrounding the Windows path with double-quotes.

```
#!script

mecab -r"C:\Program Files\MeCab\etc\mymecabrc"
```
## Version, platform, environment details
1. MeCab 0.996.exe
2. Windows XP Professional, Version 2002, Service Pack 3
3. Python 2.7.8
4. natto-py 0.0.2

Originally  opened 2014-11-05.
Archiving this issue for historical reasons.
